title: Russian Operative Maria Butina Deported
summary: Ms. Butina pleaded guilty to conspiring to influence U.S. politics during 2016 election. Maria Butina, a convicted Russian operative who infiltrated conservative groups during the 2016 presidential election, has been deported to Russia.

title: California Fires Force Thousands to Evacuate
summary: Resume Subscription. GEYSERVILLE, Calif.-Fires across California are threatening thousands of people and homes while utilities are warning that nearly one million homes and businesses could lose power starting this weekend.

title: U.S. Restores Trade Benefit to Ukraine
summary: Ukraine regains partial access to program that grants poor countries duty-free treatment on some goods. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration restored a small trade benefit to Ukraine late Friday, two years after the benefits were revoked on grounds that the country wasn't protecting U.S. intellectual property rights.

title: Pentagon Picks Microsoft for Cloud Contract Over Amazon
summary: Contract could be worth as much as $10 billion over a decade. The Pentagon awarded Microsoft Corp. a hotly contested and controversial contract to build a large cloud-computing system for the U.S. military in a major setback to rival Amazon.com Inc., which was widely seen as the front-runner.

title: Budweiser Brewer Issues Profit Warning, Sending Shares Lower
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev reported a disappointing quarter in the U.S. and China. Anheuser-Busch InBev SA cut its full-year guidance after a disappointing quarterly performance in the U.S. and China, sending its shares 10% lower and underscoring the challenges the Budweiser brewer faces despite moves to trim its enormous debt pile.

title: New California Wildfire Unsettles PG&E Bankruptcy
summary: If linked to PG&E, the Kincade Wildfire could hurt shareholders' attempt to protect their investments in the company. The wildfire ripping through Sonoma County, Calif., may have a lasting impact on who owns PG&E Corp. by making it tougher for shareholders to protect their stakes in the bankrupt utility.

title: Foreign Influence and Double Standards
summary: Democrats deplore Trump on Ukraine but not Clinton in 2016.. Democrats want to impeach Donald Trump for inviting Ukraine to investigate 2020 election rival Joe Biden. But then why are they opposed to investigating whether Democrats used Russian disinformation to get the FBI to investigate Donald Trump in 2016?

title: A Win for the Uighurs
summary: Europe bestows its Sakharov prize on an imprisoned economist.. This week a human-rights activist languishing in the Chinese gulag was awarded Europe's Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Thought, named after the famous Soviet nuclear physicist-turned-dissident. China's response tells you why the man deserved it. A Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman accused the European Parliament of intervening in China's internal affairs and celebrating "a terrorist."

title: Trump Organization Exploring Sale of Washington Hotel
summary: Move is motivated partly by ethical criticisms concerning profiting on the property. President Trump's real-estate business is considering unloading its opulent Washington, D.C., hotel, a move it says is motivated partly by criticism that the Trumps are flouting government-ethics laws by profiting from the property.

title: Fires and Blackouts Made in Sacramento
summary: Newsom tries to deflect blame, but PG&E is the agent of his policies.. After again shutting power to hundreds of thousands this week, California's utility PG&E disclosed Thursday that it had discovered a broken jumper cable by the ignition site of a wildfire blazing across Sonoma County. The company has warned of more blackouts this weekend and perhaps for the next decade as it refurbishes its aging grid.

title: Mueller Grand Jury Materials Must Be Transmitted to Congress
summary: Judge also rules Democrats' probes have legal standing as an impeachment inquiry. WASHINGTON-A federal judge ruled Congress can get its hands on grand-jury evidence collected by former special counsel Robert Mueller, and also determined that wide-ranging House inquiries into President Trump have legal standing as an impeachment investigation.

title: Snuggle, Right Guard Maker's Promotion of CFO Draws Criticism
summary: German consumer goods maker Henkel promoted its third consecutive CEO from within. Companies that promote a finance chief to chief executive often do so in the name of caution, putting the reins in what can be seen as familiar and safe hands.

title: Clashes Break Out in Northern Syria, Testing Turkish Truce
summary: Syrian government forces enter Kurdish-held areas amid six-day cease-fire. BEIRUT-Renewed clashes between Kurdish and Turkish forces tested a shaky cease-fire in northern Syria on Friday, as the Russia-backed Syrian government moved troops into the area in part of its efforts to reclaim territory it ceded during the eight-year war.

title: Former Navy Chief Joins Boeing Board
summary: Retired Navy admiral John Richardson's election is part of the broader effort to improve its plane maker's safety culture. Boeing said Friday that the former military head of the U.S. Navy has been elected to its board, part of a broader effort to improve the plane maker's safety oversight.

title: Anti-Money-Laundering Watchdog Provides More Guidance on Beneficial Ownership Transparency
summary: Financial Action Task Force requires member countries to take steps to prevent entities from being used for criminal purposes. Countries should establish systems that use one or more different methods to identify the beneficial ownership of an entity, a global anti-money-laundering watchdog said in a new report.

title: Boeing 737 MAX Design, FAA Blamed for Lion Air Crash
summary: Indonesian investigators say deficiencies in pilot training, communication contributed to crash. Indonesian investigators blamed Boeing Co. 's design and inadequate U.S. safety oversight, combined with lax maintenance and poor piloting skills, for a Lion Air 737 MAX's fatal nosedive into the Java Sea nearly a year ago.

title: House to Vote on Resolution to Mark Armenian Genocide
summary: Congress has pulled back from such step several times in recent decades, but appears willing to move forward amid tensions with Turkey. The House is poised to vote next week on a resolution to commemorate the Armenian genocide perpetrated by the Ottoman Empire, a move that supporters say is driven in part by fears of potential Turkish atrocities against the Kurds in northern Syria.

title: This Impeachment Subverts the Constitution
summary: It's nakedly political and procedurally defective, and so far there's no public evidence of high crimes.. Speaker Nancy Pelosi has directed committees investigating President Trump to "proceed under that umbrella of impeachment inquiry," but the House has never authorized such an inquiry. Democrats have been seeking to impeach Mr. Trump since the party took control of the House, though it isn't clear for what offense. Lawmakers and commentators have suggested various possibilities, but none amount to an impeachable offense. The effort is akin to a constitutionally proscribed bill of attainder-a legislative effort to punish a disfavored person. The Senate should treat it accordingly.

title: Zuckerberg vs. the Permissioncrats
summary: In attacking Facebook's proposed Libra currency, Washington only sees the downsides of social media.. To ask permission is to seek denial, goes the saying. Mark Zuckerberg sought denial at a hearing of the House Financial Services Committee this week. He made it official: Facebook would not move ahead with its digital currency project, Libra, unless and until U.S. and foreign regulators approve.

title: Tech Workers and Asians Against Racial Preferences
summary: Washington state unions try to reverse a 1998 ballot measure and bring back affirmative action.. Seattle

title: Why 'Strategic Plans' Are Rarely Strategic-or Effective
summary: Effective managers can list their goals on a note card. They don't need long recitations of bromides.. Montgomery, Ala.

title: 'Something Deeply Hidden' and 'The Number of Heavens' Review: You in Another Universe
summary: Multiverse theories may goad our imaginations, but are they good science-or science at all?. In 1990 I wrote a bit of fluff for Scientific American about whether our cosmos might be just one in an "infinitude," as several theories of physics implied. I titled my piece "Here a Universe, There a Universe . . ." and kept the tone light, because I didn't want readers to take these cosmic conjectures too seriously. After all, there was no way of proving, or disproving, the existence of other universes.

title: Facebook's Zuckerberg Urges Tech Rivals to Pay for News
summary: Social giant launches news service featuring array of news outlets and pays to license content. Facebook Inc. Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg said the social-media giant's decision to pay media outlets who participate in its news service will give a much-needed boost to the publishing industry and provides a model other internet companies should follow.

title: Procter & Gamble, Nike, Tesla: Stocks That Defined the Week
summary: Here are seven major companies whose stocks moved on the week's news. Can John Donahoe 'Just Do It'? The former eBay Inc. CEO was named late Tuesday as the new boss of Nike, succeeding longtime leader Mark Parker. The change marks a strategic shift atop the world's biggest sportswear brand. Nike has posted strong apparel and sneaker sales, but it has also faced public relations crises like the ban of Nike's top running coach amid doping allegations and concerns about the company's workplace culture. Mr. Donahoe will take over in January and Mr. Parker will become Nike's executive chairman. Nike shares fell 3.4% Wednesday.

title: Syrians Who Opposed Assad Fear Arrest as Troops Return
summary: Some residents say pact with regime's forces opens door to brutal police state in Kurdish-led enclave. When Aziz Dawood heard of the agreement struck by Kurdish forces to allow the Syrian government to return to the country's northeast, he feared regime forces would raid his house that night as he slept to arrest him.

title: PG&E Power Lines Remain Risky to California, Even During Blackouts
summary: Equipment failure before wine country fire rattles shareholders, clouds bankrupt company's future. The failure of a PG&E Corp. power line minutes before a wildfire broke out in California's wine country starkly shows how the company's electric system continues to pose risks to the safety of millions of residents, even as it takes desperate measures to reduce the threat of fire.

title: Canadian Mills' Woes Drive Up Lumber Prices
summary: Mills in British Columbia curtail production, citing beetle infestations, harvesting restrictions and tariffs. Beetles, tariffs and mill closures have cut into Canada's share of the U.S. lumber market, lifting prices by about a third over the past year and shifting even more logging to the U.S. Southeast.

title: Nashville Mayor's Unorthodox Vow: Slow Corporate Handouts
summary: Resume Subscription. NASHVILLE-This city has been a poster child for economic development, the good and the bad.

title: Stakeholder Capitalism and No Electricity
summary: Does anyone see the irony in Sacramento promoting the purchase of electric vehicles through tax subsidies and then turning off the electricity that makes them run?. Allysia Finley describes California's Pacific Gas and Electric Co. as a poster child for "'Stakeholder' Capitalism in Action" (op-ed, Oct. 22). Government, communities, consumers and environmentalists wrestled control of the utility from shareholders regarding climate-related policies, capital investments and corporate governance.

title: Patriotism: More Unum, Less Pluribus Please
summary: Two factors contribute to waning patriotism: a general lack of education at all levels in American civics, history and culture, and that there are fewer of us who have served either in the military or performed public service.. I am disappointed that Adam Kirsch's otherwise fine essay "American Patriotism Is Worth Fighting For" (Review, Oct. 19) fails to mention a new campaign to promote healthy patriotism, the Patriotic Movement, or to cite "Reclaiming Patriotism," the new book by the movement's leader, Amitai Etzioni. The laudable goals of this movement are to build up the national community and its institutions, thereby reducing polarization and facilitating cooperative action on major problems. To achieve these goals it advocates a year of national service, teaching civics in all schools, enlisting volunteers to teach English to new immigrants and conducting local and national dialogues on defining the common good and ways to advance it. At a time when division and distrust are taking a terrible toll, it is important to reinforce our common values and aspirations as citizens of one country-an imperfect one to be sure, but one that we, like generations before us, must strive to make a more perfect union.

title: Brunson and Christian History in Anatolia
summary: In the earliest days of Christianity, what is now Turkey was probably the most evangelized country in the world.. Regarding Adam O'Neal's "The Weekend Interview with Andrew Brunson: Turkey's American Hostage Speaks Out" (Oct. 5): Andrew Brunson, the unjustly imprisoned Evangelical Presbyterian Church missionary, says, "We went to Turkey because it was the largest unevangelized country in the world." But in the earliest days of Christianity, what is now Turkey was probably the most evangelized country in the world. Muslim persecution of Christians is the reason for the change.

title: Wimpification Exemplified By Toilet Paper Concerns
summary: As a child in the '40s and '50s, a visit to my grandmother's northern Minnesota, smelly outhouse meant ripping one page from the Sears catalog.. When I was a child in the 1940s and '50s, a visit to my grandmother's northern Minnesota, smelly outhouse meant ripping one page from the Sears catalog. There were no complaints of "annoying" rolls to change ("One Roll to Rule Them All: Charmin Tries to Keep the Peace," Page One, Oct. 17). A new supply arrived in the mail free once a year. Oh, America, how you've changed.

title: Judges Reject California Challenge to Changing U.S. Emissions Standards
summary: Judges said it was too early to rule on substance of legal battle over vehicle-emission standards because EPA hasn't gotten far enough in rewriting rules. A panel of federal judges threw out a legal challenge by California and several other states that want to preserve tougher vehicle-emissions standards, a win for the White House even as the judges warned the administration it couldn't disregard facts as it develops the new standards.

title: As GM Workers Approve New Labor Deal, UAW Ends 40-Day Strike
summary: Accord brings better wages to 46,000 blue-collar workers and allows General Motors to move forward with closing three U.S. factories. After 40 days of picketing, the United Auto Workers union is ending its nationwide strike at General Motors Co.

title: S&P 500 Flirts With Record Levels
summary: The index briefly traded above its July 26 closing high but later pared gains. The S&P 500 made a run at its record Friday-but came up short-as optimism on trade and a fresh batch of earnings results propelled the index to its third consecutive week of gains.

title: Mexico's Failure to Stem Violence Strains Relationship With U.S.
summary: Resume Subscription. MEXICO CITY-Last week, hundreds of gunmen from the Sinaloa cartel overpowered military forces in fighting that killed at least a dozen people, blocked the airport and major roads, and terrorized the city of Culiacán for hours until the Mexican government capitulated and freed the son of legendary drug lord Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzmán.

title: Trump Administration Makes It Harder for Immigrants to Claim Fee Waivers
summary: Applicants for citizenship or other legal status won't be able to cite receipt of government benefits. WASHINGTON-Immigrants applying for citizenship or other legal status will no longer be able to use receipt of government benefits as a condition to seek a waiver of an application fee under a policy change announced Friday by U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services.

title: U.S. Deficit Hits Seven-Year High
summary: Federal spending climbed 8%, while revenue increased only 4%, in fiscal year ending in September. WASHINGTON-The U.S. spent nearly $1 trillion more in fiscal 2019 than it took in-the highest deficit in seven years that would have been bigger without a rebound in corporate tax revenue.

title: The Drones Are Coming! Uber, Amazon, Alphabet Take Flight
summary: Resume Subscription. Flying robots that deliver packages to people's doorsteps are no longer science fiction. Companies including Amazon.com Inc., Alphabet Inc.'s Wing and Uber Technologies Inc. are starting the most advanced trials of drone delivery in U.S. history.

title: Schwab Shows Strength While Rival E-Brokers Lag Behind
summary: TD Ameritrade, E*Trade have rebounded since start of zero-commission price war, but not as much as Schwab. Chuck Schwab's zero-commission gambit is paying off.

title: Mourners Pay Tribute to Cummings's Faith, Zeal Against Corruption
summary: Former presidents Obama and Clinton were among those who paid their respects to the late lawmaker in Baltimore. The late Rep. Elijah Cummings (D., Md.) was remembered Friday as a lawmaker willing to work across the aisle but capable of holding officials accountable.

title: Preterm Birth Treatment Isn't Effective, Study Finds
summary: Long recommended weekly injection of synthetic progestin hormone Makena for women faces new scrutiny. The standard treatment to prevent women from having another preterm birth isn't effective, according to the final results of a study. The finding has already led at least one maternal medicine group to revamp its guidelines.

title: Trump Denounces Envoy Bill Taylor, Who Linked Aid to Pressure
summary: House committees will interview several administration officials next week. WASHINGTON-President Trump denounced U.S. envoy Bill Taylor and suggested it was a mistake for the secretary of state to have sent him to Kyiv, after the diplomat testified this past week that Mr. Trump directed that aid to Ukraine to be contingent on the country announcing investigations that Mr. Trump sought.

title: China Sets Up New $29 Billion Semiconductor Fund
summary: Government-backed fund is part of continuing effort by China to become less dependent on U.S. technology. BEIJING-China has set up a new national semiconductor fund of 204.2 billion yuan ($28.9 billion), as it seeks to nurture its domestic chip industry and close the technology gap with the U.S.

title: U.S. Watchdog Council Says DOJ Erred in Blocking Ukraine Whistleblower Complaint
summary: Memo saying matter wasn't urgent was wrong, Council of Inspectors General concludes. A U.S. watchdog council has faulted a Justice Department legal memo that initially blocked the Ukraine whistleblower's complaint, which sparked the impeachment investigation, from reaching Congress.

title: World Series in Washington: Trump Officials, 'Never Trumpers' and Lobbyists
summary: With Nationals up 2-0, the series is bringing together many people who don't always gather together. WASHINGTON-Thousands of lobbyists, lawmakers, "Never Trumpers," Democrats and a hefty dose of rest of the political establishment, all sitting cheek-by-jowl.

title: U.K. Police Make More Arrests in Truck Deaths Case
summary: Three more people in addition to driver are held on suspicion of manslaughter and human trafficking. British police have made more arrests after the discovery of 39 bodies in a refrigerated truck earlier this week near London, detaining a man and woman in northern England and another man at London's Stansted Airport, all on suspicion of manslaughter and trafficking the victims into the U.K.

title: Verizon Boosts Subscribers, Aided by New Pricing Plans
summary: Carrier added 444,000 net new postpaid phone connections in third quarter. Verizon Communications Inc. notched large gains in phone subscribers in the third quarter, aided by a revamp of its unlimited data plans that shaved about $5 off customers' monthly bills.

title: Smashing Pumpkins to Save the 'Hollow'
summary: Washington Irving's 'The Legend of Sleepy Hollow' is a quintessential Halloween horror story-but it's also a tale that delivers laughs as well as deeper lessons about protecting communities..

title: Boris Johnson Wants a Brexit Election. He May Not Get It.
summary: Prime minister needs Labour's support for Dec. 12 general election but the opposition hasn't decided whether to give it. LONDON-The first time British Prime Minister Boris Johnson urged the main opposition Labour Party to trigger an election to clear a path to Brexit, last month, his advisers were confident Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn would comply.

title: Mourners Praise Rep. Elijah Cummings at His Funeral
summary: Mourners gathered in Baltimore to celebrate the life of Maryland Rep. Elijah Cummings who died last week. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: U.S. Moves to Further Isolate Iran From Global Finance System
summary: Washington's latest action forces U.S. banks to scour their foreign business relationships for any transactions with Iran. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration moved on Friday to further isolate Iran from the global financial system by declaring the country a "jurisdiction of primary money laundering concern."

title: An Artist Looking at Himself
summary: Lucian Freud's self-portraits reveal his evolution as a painter and a man.. In a 2002 self-portrait, Lucian Freud (1922-2011) depicted himself as a gaunt figure, his plume of gray hair askew, one veiny hand clutching his scarf.

title: Has Trump Inflicted Enough Pain on China Yet?
summary: The U.S. is also suffering from the trade fight.. How much economic pressure is enough to persuade China's communist dictator Xi Jinping to change his business model? So far his trade dispute with the U.S. is inflicting more financial pain than he'll admit but not enough to force economic liberalization. This means that to maintain a strong U.S. economy and get re-elected, Donald Trump needs a plan B for trade expansion if Beijing disappoints him again at the bargaining table. Cutting a soft bargain with the rest of the world would drive a resurgence in U.S. business investment. Slashing U.S. tariffs on goods coming from places other than China would also exert even more competitive pressure on Beijing.

title: Meth Is Top Drug in the West for Overdose Deaths
summary: Fentanyl remains the top drug in overdose deaths nationwide, but methamphetamine is becoming more prevalent. Methamphetamine, or "meth," the powerful man-made alternative to plant-based stimulants like cocaine and crack, is playing a bigger role in fatal overdoses in the western half of the U.S. than the synthetic opioid fentanyl.

title: Sears Explores Selling Off DieHard Brand
summary: Retailer has hired Guggenheim to advise on potential sale of battery brand and other assets as it continues to struggle postbankruptcy. The parent of Sears has hired investment bankers to advise it on potential asset sales, including the DieHard brand, according to people familiar with the situation, as the chain continues to struggle.

title: The Truth Squad Takes Aim at Facebook
summary: Mark Zuckerberg is right: Private companies shouldn't be policing public debate.. Mark Zuckerberg's headlong fall from epoch-shaping, world-connecting, community-building billionaire to monopoly-protecting, hate-speech-promoting, election-rigging avatar of evil (but still a billionaire, so there are some consolations) shows no sign of abating. He was on Capitol Hill again this week, adopting a gentle demeanor of saintly submission while under the lash from lawmakers.

title: Businesses Fear U.S., China Won't Reach Trade Deal on Core Issues
summary: The White House is hoping to have a phase one deal ready by mid-November, when it could potentially be signed by President Trump and China's President Xi Jinping. WASHINGTON-American companies cheered when the U.S. and China called a cease-fire in their trade war this month, but as both sides work toward drafting an initial deal some worry that a more meaningful, long-term pact may never be reached.

title: At Least 'Quid Pro Quo' Has Revived Latin
summary: But have we attained the 'sine qua non' or reached the 'ne plus ultra'?. These are thrilling times for those of us who took Latin in school. The ubiquitous use of the term quid pro quo (essentially, "something for something") to describe the president's controversial offer to the Ukrainian government has gotten classicists excited in a way not seen since the heady days of the 1980s, when the word qua was much in use. (It means "as," as in, "She's a great singer qua singer, but she's too old to play Goldilocks.")

title: Is 3-D Printing the Future of Terrorism?
summary: In a Yom Kippur synagogue attack, a far-right German extremist hoped to inspire other killers to put an emerging technology to lethal use. On Oct. 9, a gunman tried to massacre worshipers on Yom Kippur at a synagogue in Halle, Germany, and crossed a new threshold: It was the first time a terrorist perpetrated a deadly attack with homemade weapons using 3-D-printed components-including a 3-D-printed gun.

title: Citigroup's Consumer Strategy Is Starting to Pay Off
summary: Head of global consumer banking at Citigroup may be leaving, but results in the laggard unit have actually been improving. The global head of Citigroup 's consumer business is leaving. Yet things are actually heading in the right direction for that part of the banking giant.

title: Defense Chief Affirms U.S. Troop Shift to Syrian Oil Fields
summary: Mark Esper says forces and equipment will guard facilities against Islamic State. BRUSSELS-Defense Secretary Mark Esper said the U.S. would be reinforcing its defense of oil fields in northeastern Syria, as American plans shift away from President Trump's full troop withdrawal.

title: Democratic National Committee Boosts Requirements for 6th Debate
summary: The changes could result in fewer candidates qualifying for December debate. The Democratic National Committee said Friday it would raise the threshold for participation in the sixth presidential primary debate on Dec. 19 in California, a move likely to winnow down the number of candidates on stage from the dozen who participated in mid-October.

title: Fed Adds $77.3 Billion in Weekend Liquidity
summary: Resume Subscription. The New York Fed injected permanent and temporary liquidity into financial markets Friday.

title: Darkness Has Descended on Denver. Most of Its Sports Teams Are Off TV.
summary: A contract dispute means all three pay-television systems are blocking Nuggets and Avalanche games, a situation unheard of in recent sports history. Denver sports fans are facing a philosophical conundrum. If a game is played and no one watches, did it really happen?

title: The NBA's New Normal in China
summary: The Houston Rockets played their first game of the season. Chinese state TV broadcast Military World Games basketball instead. After media blackouts and protests, what happens next for the NBA?. China, the biggest international market for the National Basketball Association, greeted the start of a new season with media blackouts, missing sponsors and airbrushed images.

title: Russian Soldier Kills Eight Service Members in Base Shooting
summary: Attack occurred during a guard change; suspect detained. A Russian soldier shot and killed eight fellow servicemen Friday on a military base in the country's far east, the defense ministry said, the bloodiest incident of gun violence on a Russian military base in recent years.

title: Mon Dieu! Is China Now a Better Place to Do Business Than France?
summary: Study concluding that China is an easier place to do business than France is highly misleading. China now tops France in the World Bank's latest "Doing Business" rankings and is closing in on Japan. But there is less than meets the eye to the stratospheric rise in its rank, from 78th to 31st in just three years, making it supposedly one of the easiest emerging markets in which to do business.

title: Rethinking Food: 5 Podcasts and Indie Magazines That Do It Best
summary: We've paired them for your listening and perusing pleasure. Turn on, tune in, eat up. Ox Tales: Each year, chefs, scholars, scientists and other musers on matters culinary assemble in England for the Oxford Symposium on Food & Cookery. This podcast makes the most interesting research presented there accessible in the form of engaging audio stories. In one episode, a Japanese food historian unpacks the cultural significance of slurping. In another, a third-generation foie gras producer grapples with the passion and opprobrium inspired by her livelihood. oxfordsymposium.org.uk/podcasts

title: The Houston Astros Dig a Deeper Hole
summary: The American League champs are down 2-0 in the World Series. Off the field, it's considerably worse.. The Houston Astros need help, quick. The American League Champions are sinking, entering Friday night's World Series Game 3 down 2-0 to the upstart Washington Nationals.

title: Photos of the Week
summary: GOP lawmakers storm impeachment hearing, Trudeau wins re-election, U.S. troops withdraw from Syria and more. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Five Best: Catherine Bailey on Evocations of Italy
summary: From the author, most recently, of 'A Castle in Wartime.. By Carlo Levi (1945)

title: Mysteries: Death, Doubt and Doubling Down
summary: 'Good Man Gone Bad" is Gar Anthony Haywood's seventh novel-and best yet-to feature the 60-year-old African-American PI Aaron Gunner. Aaron Gunner, the 60-year-old African-American private investigator in Gar Anthony Haywood's gritty "Good Man Gone Bad" (Prospect Park, 236 pages, $16), lives and works in a part of Los Angeles "well east of the great class divide that was La Cienega Boulevard." As such, he's no stranger to harsh fates and dire deeds. But even he is shaken by the news that his cousin Del Curry has killed his wife, wounded their 22-year-old daughter and committed suicide.

title: 'Find Me' Review: Better Left Unspoken
summary: A much-anticipated sequel that dispenses with many of the ingredients that made the earlier book so moving.. Literary sequels are tricky. When a book is beautiful enough to stoke demands for more, it probably means the author should leave well enough alone. Unless the hero goes by Rabbit, Smiley or Zuckerman, the result tends to be uneven. Alas, such is the case with "Find Me," André Aciman's much-anticipated follow-up to his luminous debut novel, "Call Me by Your Name" (2007), made famous by an Oscar-winning adaptation in 2017. It is only natural to want more time with Elio and Oliver, who are a precocious 17 and a dapper 24 when they fall deeply and desirously in love over a few precious weeks on the Italian Riviera. But as one insufferable character in the new novel implies but doesn't quite say: Closure is for the dogs.

title: America Can't Escape the Middle East
summary: The U.S. has sought to pull back from the region after a series of setbacks and mistakes, but a range of national interests-and the need to maintain global standing-have kept American forces on the ground. Ever since the national trauma of the war in Iraq, both winning presidential candidates have run on pledges to extricate the U.S. from costly Middle Eastern entanglements.

title: 'Lampedusa' Review: Spotting the Leopard
summary: A historical novel about the Sicilian prince who wrote a superb work of ﬁction about the birth of Italy.. Giuseppe Tomasi, Prince of Lampedusa and Duke of Palma, had two more titles than anyone needs, and, for the first 58 years of his life, too much time-numbingly vast stretches of largely undistinguished, unencumbered years in a Sicily that was always, in his words, "hankering for voluptuous immobility." When some lock in him finally turned around 1955, he began work on one of the most magisterial and delicate works of 20th-century fiction, racing to complete and publish it before death overtook him in 1957. (He died at age 60 three weeks after his manuscript was rejected for the second time by a publisher.) Published at last a year after his death, "The Leopard," about the rise of republicanism and the end of feudalism in Sicily in the 1860s, is politically ambiguous, written from the perspective of the Sicilian nobles but also revealing their (sometimes) lovable uselessness. Some early critics met "The Leopard" with condescending stupefaction: Who was this Sicilian parvenu, whose death conveniently prevented his being made to account for himself? But the later emergence of Tomasi di Lampedusa's letters, stories and essays revealed a mind that had been churning continuously, devouring the literature and vernacular of half a dozen languages and dessicating his singular wit to a dryness extreme even by the standards of his half-desert home of Palermo.

title: Fiction: Store-Bought Solutions to All Our Ills
summary: A corporate thriller about a certain mammoth e-tailer with plans for world domi-nation.. For as long as there have been powerful companies there have been novels assailing their authoritarian tendencies, from Frank Norris's muckraking exposé of railroad trusts in "The Octopus" to Aldous Huxley's dystopian satire on Henry Ford's mass-production innovations in "Brave New World" to Dave Eggers's dark vision of an all-seeing Silicon Valley tech colossus in "The Circle." The latest corporate cautionary tale is Rob Hart's "The Warehouse" (Crown, 358 pages, $27), about the mammoth e-retailer Cloud, which has expanded in an environmentally ravaged near-future to dominate America's economy and usurp its government. The jacket image depicting towers of brown shipping boxes and a drone hovering ominously above them gives away Mr. Hart's real-world target.

title: What Presidents Ensnared in Impeachment Said-in Their Own Words
summary: All four leaders defended themselves vigorously against the accusations they faced. Only four presidents have ever been embroiled in impeachment proceedings. Andrew Johnson and Bill Clinton were acquitted after Senate trials, while Richard Nixon resigned in the face of a likely impeachment trial and conviction. The investigation into President Trump continues.

title: 'The Fire Is Upon Us' Review: The Great Race Debate
summary: In 1965, James Baldwin and William F. Buckley Jr. faced off at the University of Cambridge.. It was the publicist at the London publisher Corgi who, in January 1965, in collaboration with some students, had the bright idea of bringing James Baldwin to the Cambridge Union to take part in a formal debate. At the turn of 1965, Baldwin was, in the words of one writer of the time, "the monarch of the current literary jungle." "The Fire Next Time," his eloquent plea for racial understanding-which in Baldwin's terms meant human understanding-had spent a year on the best-seller lists after publication in 1963. "Another Country," his novel of racial and sexual integration in action, had been similarly successful the year before. Although hardly "among the 5 or 6 most famous people in the world," as William Styron said, in words cited by Nicholas Buccola in "The Fire Is Upon Us," Baldwin was nonetheless a significant presence on the national stage at a moment when the United States was in crisis over the mounting exasperation of its black population, especially in the South. The force of his moral outlook was felt in Britain, too, which had recently seen the arrival of immigrants from colonial lands.

title: Children's Books: Making Friends With Fear
summary: 'Skulls are not trying to be scary. They can't help the way they look.'. Winston Churchill once said that there's nothing more exhilarating than being shot at without result. The same goes for the reading of spooky stories. There's vicarious dread and mounting terror and then-whoosh!-a kind of escape. Whatever ghastly thing may happen on the page, the reader at least gets away with limbs intact.

title: 'Big Wonderful Thing' Review: The Texas Dream
summary: A Texas-size history makes clear that the Lone Star state, like the United States as a whole, has always absorbed and resisted newcomers; it also has always made claims to an "exceptional" status.. I lived in Texas for 45 years, in the place but never of it. Stationed there, I developed a fondness for its expansive history (even more, its mythology), landscapes, food, vastness. It was never home.

title: 'Dreams of El Dorado' Review: Mountains, Rivers and Deserts
summary: America's conquest of the West wasn't foreordained. After learning of the cataracts on the Missouri and Columbia rivers, President Jefferson concluded the Far West might be too remote to ever join the United States.. Like emigrants loading their Conestogas for a cross-country trek, authors of one-volume histories of the American West have some tough choices to make. Faced with limited space and an overwhelming subject, do they cram in bloodless dates and events while leaving behind humanizing material such as anecdotes and first-person accounts? Or do they pack in vivid characters and rousing stories, at the expense of detail, insight and analysis?

title: 'The Mutual Admiration Society' Review: The Case of the Lifelong Friends
summary: The mystery writer Dorothy L. Sayers-creator of Lord Peter Wimsy-was the center of a circle of remarkable women.. Dorothy L. Sayers, to many the quintessential British mystery writer, is best known as the creator of Lord Peter Wimsey, the quintessentially aristocratic sleuth who tootles along to murder scenes in his Daimler, his monocled eye missing nothing. "It was rather obvious, really," Wimsey typically remarks, "smoothing back his hair" when he has cracked another case. But there is more to Wimsey, particularly in the later novels, than cleverness-war-wounded, he is prone to nervous collapse-and there was always a great deal more to Sayers.

title: Putting the Buy-and-Hold Gospel to the Ultimate Test
summary: Think you know the lessons from 'Black Monday'? Think again.. One of the best ways to make sure the easy gains of the past 10 years haven't made you complacent is to look back at the Crash of 1929.

title: Could a Ski Hill, a Theme Park and 40 Water Slides Save the American Mall?
summary: American Dream, the most expensive U.S. mall ever built, is now open-and the industry is watching. East Rutherford, N.J.-From the New Jersey Turnpike, the American Dream mall's white shell resembles so many other enclosed shopping centers around the country, just on a larger scale. Its audacious premise hits you when you step inside. It's all about the spectacle.

title: SoftBank Fund Dials Down Risk; Staff Struggles With Chaotic Culture
summary: After WeWork debacle, Masayoshi Son pivots from the grow-at-all-costs strategy at startups. After suffering billions of dollars of losses on its investment in WeWork, SoftBank Group Corp.'s Vision Fund is scaling back its high-risk investing strategy and focusing more on improving corporate governance at portfolio companies, according to current and former executives at the fund.

title: Today's Logistics Report: Amazon's Shipping Costs Soar; Supply Chain Tapestry; Trade's Tight Window
summary: Today's Top Supply Chain & Logistics News from WSJ. Sign up: With one click, get this newsletter delivered to your inbox.

title: Democratic Voters, Donors Give Buttigieg a Fresh Look
summary: 'We're hitting another...upswing,' says South Bend, Ind., mayor once considered a presidential long shot. Shortly after 12 presidential candidates stepped off the debate stage earlier this month, roughly two-dozen influential Democrats at a watch party held an informal survey to see which White House contenders made an impression during the three-hour event.

title: The Hapless Gang That Hacked Trump's Inauguration
summary: Resume Subscription. Eight days before Donald Trump's presidential inauguration, the Secret Service received an urgent call saying hackers had seized control of most of the video surveillance cameras that keep watch over the U.S. capital.

title: Stephen Swid Found a Fortune in Obscure Corners of Music Industry
summary: Entrepreneur collected royalties for stars including Bob Dylan and Neil Diamond. In a career devoted to tracking down and acquiring undervalued businesses, Stephen Swid invested in makers of carpet padding and Knoll office furniture. He and a partner tried unsuccessfully to take over Sotheby's auction house. He owned Spin magazine and a movie-production company.

title: Paul Polak Built Better Tools for Farmers in Poor Countries
summary: Psychiatrist turned entrepreneur deployed market forces in quest to eliminate poverty. Paul Polak, a refugee from Nazi persecution, became a successful psychiatrist and real estate investor in Denver. In his late 40s, he reinvented himself into what would now be called a social entrepreneur.

title: Vaping Bans Raise Fear of Return to Smoking
summary: Sales of regular cigarettes are expected to improve as a result of e-cigarette restrictions. Vaping bans and other crackdowns on access to vaping products are spurring a backlash among both past smokers and some public-health experts.

title: Trump Says He Will Attend World Series in Washington
summary: The Nationals hold a 2-0 lead in the best-of-seven series against the Houston Astros. WASHINGTON-President Trump said he planned to attend the World Series on Sunday, when Washington is hosting game five of the matchup between the hometown Nationals and the Houston Astros.

title: We May Not Have to Age So Fast
summary: Researchers in epigenetics are learning how to slow down-and even turn back-the clock that governs aging in our cells. We all age chronologically with the passage of time, but what about our bodies? Is physiological aging inevitable too? A growing cadre of biologists is starting to say no, thanks to developments in the field of epigenetics, which studies not our DNA itself but the processes that determine how our genes "express" themselves in directing our cells throughout our lives.

title: How the Kurds Gained, Then Lost, a Syrian Enclave
summary: Resume Subscription. President Trump this month ordered most U.S. troops to leave Syria, paving the way for a Turkish military operation against Kurdish-led militias that had helped the U.S. in the fight against Islamic State.

title: Pittsburgh Prepares for First Anniversary of Tree of Life Synagogue Shooting
summary: Amid commemorations of the deadliest anti-Semitic attack in U.S. history, plans to rebuild the synagogue. PITTSBURGH-A year after the deadliest anti-Semitic attack in U.S. history, the Tree of Life synagogue remains closed.

title: Schumer Lays Out Climate Proposal
summary: Senate minority leader is outlining the agenda he would pursue if Democrats take control of the chamber in 2020. This item first appeared in the Capital Journal newsletter. Read today's full newsletter here or sign up here for daily updates in your inbox.

title: Budweiser's Owner Has a Troubling New Brew
summary: The world's largest beer company has served up a profit warning and weak growth in key markets. Budweiser's parent is getting its debt down to more manageable levels, but has sullied the brew with a profit warning and poor growth in key markets.

title: 'World Series': From Baseball to Poker, a Title That Aspires to Span the Planet
summary: The major-league championship is still mostly a U.S. affair, but others using the term have gone truly global. Major League Baseball's World Series, as usual, isn't exactly worldly this year. The matchup of the American League's Houston Astros and the National League's Washington Nationals pits two teams representing the parochial confines of the U.S. Only in 1992 and 1993 has the baseball championship included a non-American team, when the Toronto Blue Jays competed and won both years, bringing glory to Canada.

title: Brexit Uncertainty Stuck On a Permanent Extension
summary: U.K. politics remain deadlocked, and even if a deal is passed, the details of Brexit are still to be negotiated. Investors awaiting clarity on Brexit shouldn't wait around.

title: Chinese Conglomerate Said to Weigh Sale of Trophy Asset
summary: China Minsheng Investment plans to sell Sirius International Insurance Group if it gets a good price, people familiar with discussions say. A once-highflying Chinese conglomerate has earmarked for sale its controlling stake in Nasdaq-listed Sirius International Insurance Group , according to people familiar with the matter, as pressure mounts from shareholders and creditors for a solution to its debt crisis.

title: Stocks to Watch: Amazon, Intel, Visa, Aflac, Weyerhaeuser and More
summary: Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively Friday. Here are some of the companies with shares expected to trade actively in Friday's session. Stock movements noted by ticker reflect movements during regular trading hours; premarket trading is specified separately.

title: Researchers Find Racial Bias in Hospital Algorithm
summary: Healthier white patients were ranked the same as sicker black patients, according to study published in the journal Science. Black patients were less likely than white patients to get extra medical help, despite being sicker, when an algorithm used by a large hospital chose who got the additional attention, according to a new study underscoring the risks as technology gains a foothold in medicine.

title: The Crooner Making Gen Z Love Songs
summary: Part Eminem, part...Ed Sheeran? How the diffident pop-rapper Rex Orange County is all heart. In a one cartoonish motion, British singer-songwriter Alex O'Connor, who goes by the stage name Rex Orange County, hit himself in the face with his microphone.

title: It's Rugby World Cup Semifinal Time: Round Up the Usual Suspects
summary: After weeks, the tournament is left with England, Wales, South Africa and New Zealand. Of course.. Twenty of the world's best rugby teams have spent the past five weeks knocking the stuffing out of each other, all to confirm what the British bookmakers could have told you two months ago. The semifinalists of the Rugby World Cup are England, South Africa, Wales and New Zealand-just like the bookies called it.

title: When Being a Dual Threat Quarterback Actually Hurts
summary: Ohio State quarterback Justin Fields does it all for the Buckeyes. His runs boost the score, but also his chance of getting injured.. In the last decade, Ohio State's football team has always been a legitimate contender for the Big Ten title. But each year there was an obvious Achilles' heel-a leaky secondary or a quarterback who runs too slow-that kept the Buckeyes from dominating opponents.

title: 10 Deservedly Famous Lists by Famous People
summary: These notes by notables-from Charles Darwin to Marilyn Monroe-highlight strategies to succeed, die happy and just get on with life as an icon. The List: A cheeky variation on a daily to-do

title: Climate-Activist Countries Fuel Record Year for Green Bonds
summary: Chile and the Netherlands have issued about $9 billion in 2019 to help fund environmental projects. When Chilean finance officials hit the road this spring for their annual meetings with bond investors, they took their sales pitch to an unlikely destination: Helsinki.

title: Liesel Pritzker Simmons on Getting Past Guilt and Making an Impact
summary: Philanthropist and co-founder of Blue Haven Initiative shares the benefits of impact investing in WSJ's 'Secrets of Wealthy Women' podcast. Even when she was younger, Liesel Pritzker Simmons says she was aware of her good fortune.

title: Presidential Candidate Tulsi Gabbard Won't Seek Re-Election to Congress
summary: Representative from Hawaii is attempting to qualify for party's next debate in Georgia. WASHINGTON-Democratic presidential candidate Tulsi Gabbard said Friday that she would not seek re-election to Congress next year, saying she could best serve the people of Hawaii as president.

title: Barclays: Vindication, for Now
summary: Barclays' Jes Staley scores a win in debate over strategy. Barclays ' strong third-quarter results amount to a vindication of Chief Executive Jes Staley's strategy. But, as in politics, there are no permanent victories in banking.

title: 10 Places to Travel in 2020-Before Everyone Else Does
summary: Some of these spots are just starting to build buzz, others are luring travelers back. All are worth adding to next year's travel itinerary. One of the wilder Caribbean islands, Dominica has been working to recover from the devastating storms that swept across it in 2015 and 2017. The rainforest is green again, classic resorts have rebuilt and upgraded, and posh new ones are springing up. Longtime favorite Jungle Bay reopened this summer in a new spot overlooking Soufriere Bay (from $325 a night, junglebaydominica.com) and there's a new 151-room Cabrits Resort & Spa Kempinski next to one of the island's three national parks (from $555 a night, kempinski.com).

title: It's a Jungle in There: The Insects and Bugs Hiding in Our Homes
summary: Average home harbors about 100 species of spiders, flies and other bugs, study finds. Next week, pint-size ghouls will descend upon neighborhoods in search of Halloween treats. But there's no need to look outside for masked monsters when myriad creatures lurk within.

title: Small Donors Get Creative to Give Over and Over to 2020 Candidates
summary: The trend is fueled by the increasing ease of giving money online. WASHINGTON-The February day that Sen. Bernie Sanders began his second Democratic presidential campaign, Christine Peloza gave him $27, the amount Mr. Sanders often boasted was the average donation in his first run. Then, she kept giving, in $3 increments, clicking donate up to 20 times a day.

title: Barclays Warns Over U.K. Economic Uncertainty
summary: CEO defends business model saying it allows the bank to weather 'today's macro headwinds'. Barclays PLC posted record revenue in its investment bank in the third quarter but warned that its U.K. business is feeling effects from Britain's planned departure from the European Union.

title: Argentine Crisis Clears Way for a Populist Return to Power
summary: Resume Subscription. MORENO, Argentina-In this gritty, industrial suburb of textile factories and slaughterhouses, the promises of President Mauricio Macri to create new jobs and transform Argentina into a modern economy have evaporated.

title: Conservatives Fault Pick for Homeland Security
summary: Chad Wolf is called not tough enough on immigration enforcement; Kevin McCarthy tipped Trump against holding G-7 meeting at resort. CONSERVATIVE GROUPS push back on White House pick for next acting secretary of the Department of Homeland Security. The groups are skeptical Chad Wolf is tough enough on immigration enforcement, based on his time as former Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen's chief of staff. White House immigration point person Stephen Miller supports his nomination, and the White House has been calling conservative organizations to reassure them.

title: A Crash Will Come. And That's OK.
summary: Trying to prepare for the next cataclysm could mean missing some of the market's best days. A crash is coming.

title: Google Offers Peek at Secretive Search Algorithm Changes
summary: Search-engine giant says one in 10 queries (and some advertisements) will see improved results from algorithm change. MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.-Google rarely talks about its secretive search algorithm. This week, the tech giant took a stab at transparency, unveiling changes that it says will surface more accurate and intelligent responses to hundreds of millions of queries each day.

title: Barr's Review of Russia Probe Shifts Into Criminal Investigation
summary: Prosecutors gain subpoena power in controversial inquiry into origins of FBI counterintelligence case. Attorney General William Barr's expanding review of the Russia probe has evolved into a criminal investigation, according to a person familiar with the matter, giving a federal prosecutor who is leading the inquiry the ability to subpoena witnesses and use a grand jury.

summary: Resume Subscription.
